Award.AwardTitle: "Physical, Engineering and Biological Limits to Brain Measurements" hosted by the University of Chicago, Chicago, IL, May 30-31, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration: The three-day workshop "Physical, Engineering and Biological Limits to Brain Measurements" hosted by the University of Chicago on May 29-31, 2014 will bring together researchers from physics, computational science, biology, and network theory to discuss the foundations of brain science and recent methodological developments in the field. The meeting is inspired in part by ongoing discussions surrounding the BRAIN initiative about the development of new technologies and tools that will help us understand how the brain works and make transformative progress in engineering and medicine. An important part of the discussion will be how to substantially improve the spatial and temporal resolution, miniaturization, numbers of probes or actuators, etc. in brain related experiments. One of the questions that will be discussed is the fundamental limits set by physics (e.g. electrical, optical and wireless methods cannot violate Maxwell's equations), engineering and material science, and from biology (e.g. one cannot over-heat the brain by dissipating too much power). The meeting will bring together practicing experts to have a systematic discussion about these limits, resulting in a written document that can be broadly disseminated to help different parties in understanding the issues, to delineate possible/impossible boundaries and to point to areas requiring further research. This is a small, focused meeting with approximately 30 participants, with a single session attended by the whole group over the meeting period. The meeting will constitute sequential discussions of the different frequency ranges of the Maxwell's equation (EEG/MEG at low frequencies, MRI, wired/wireless, optical, and x-ray), with additional segments on electron microscopy, on a general framework spanning the frequency ranges, and statistics/inverse problems. Young scientists will have the opportunity to interact with the senior investigators in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The BRAIN initiative foresees a substantial investment in new physical measurement tools on the brain, on neural function, and on neural diseases. The architecture of the brain is defined by synaptic connections on the scale of 10 nanometers, while the physical size of the brain is of course much larger. Simply to map the brain on the scale of 10 nm would generate a zettabyte of data - about the amount of information that flows over the internet in a year. Part of the challenge is of course to design methods that can minimally invasively interrogate brain function. This is a major challenge, and a recent workshop asked fundamental questions about the physical limits of measurement in the brain.

An NSF workshop in May 2014 (co-organizers: Lee, Littlewood, Martin, Mitra)  discussed the physical limits of measurement in neuroscience. The meeting set out a research agenda for Measurement Limits. Maxwell’s equations provide a unifying framework for many of the imaging/recording techniques, ordered by the wavelength of radiation: EEG/MEG as well as wired recordings in the long wavelength limit, and microwave/wireless, optical and x-ray microscopy at progressively smaller wavelengths. Closely related are the wave equations for acoustic/ultrasound based methods as well as electron microscopy. The measurement theory and the limits have historically been most thoroughly studied in the case of optical microscopy, although even in this case there continue to be research challenges, eg the usage of adaptive optics to overcome aberrations due to refractive index variations in order to image activity in deeper layers of cortex, or combining optical and acoustic techniques to image non-invasively deep within scattering neural tissue. In other cases, measurement limits remain unclear and limited by a combination of factors (eg. the smallest wireless transmitter that can be transmit neural activity measurements from inside brains), remain to be more thoroughly explored in the context of brains (x-ray microscopy) and may be pushed by innovative combinations (combining ultrasound with EEG/MEG being a promising case for future studies, in parallel with optical-acoustic methods). Further, even where the measurement limits for a particular apparatus may have been well studied in non-neuroscience contexts, there are special considerations that require further study when measuring brain activity/structure, eg. exploiting the correlations in neural activity/structure to employ compressed sensing techniques to improve temporal resolution.
